moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5: Sicilian: Rossolimo Attack.  I often play Bb5 against the Sicilian to avoid standard opening lines.
moves.3... d6 4. d4: 0-0 is the book move, but d4 pushes the aggressive center attack.
moves.4... cxd4 5. Nxd4: Qxd4 is historically more common and successful.
moves.7. Bxc6+ bxc6 8. O-O Nf6 9. Nc3 e6 10. B: e5?!  The pawn push creates an isolated pawn on c6 and doubled pawns on the e-file.
moves.16. Rad1: White mounts a coordinated attack on the central squares.
moves.16... Rad8 17. Rd3 f5: f5? is a premature attempt to chase the Knight.  Better was Bb4.
moves.18. Nxd6 Rxd6 19. Qxe5: Qxe5!  White has a fork against the Black Rook on h8 and the f5 pawn (the e6 pawn is pinned).
moves.19... Rhd8 20. Qc5: Qc5? loses the advantage.  Qxf5 and White was ahead.
moves.20... Qb6 21. Qxb6 axb6 22. Rxd6 Rxd6: The position is equal.  White has the better pawn structure, but Black's Rook and King are more active.
moves.23. g3 Rd2 24. Rc1 Kd6 25. b4 Kd5 26. c4: cxb5? If c5 Black had winning chances to capture the backward pawns on a4 and c4.
moves.30. Rc3+: The position is equal and headed for a draw.
